class SitesLattice(object):
    """ This class is a wrapper class for catkit.gen.adsorption.AdsorptionSites and focuses on analysis of 
    the slab surface attributes.
    In the documentation, "site" refers to a single site on the surface. "Edge" refers to 2 sites (generally bidentate)
    and "cluster" refers to a group of sites.

    For example:
        # SitesLattice class can be instatiated from a slab structure using the class method:
        sites = SitesLattice.from_slab(slab)
        # Site properties
        avg_coord_num = sites.avg_coord_num     # Average coordination number of surface atoms
        decorated_slab = sites.decorated_slab()  # Atoms object showing all adsorption sites

    Attributes:
        _sites (AdsorptionSites): Copy of Catkit's AdsorptionSites object.
        top_coords (list): List of top sites.
        slab (Atoms): Copy of the slab.
        cell (list): Copy of the cell.
        avg_coord_num (list): Average coordination number of the surface atoms.
    """

    def __init__(self,
                 sites: AdsorptionSites,
                 selected_sites: Union[np.ndarray, None] = None,
                 precomputed_hash: Union[List[int], None] = None):

        self._sites = sites

        # indices are used to name the different sites in _sites
        self._original_indices = np.array(range(len(sites.coordinates)))

        # list of selected sites of interest
        if selected_sites is None:
            selected_sites = self._original_indices

        self.selected_sites = np.array(selected_sites)
        self.precomputed_hash = precomputed_hash

    def __hash__(self):
        return hash(tuple(self._sites.slab.get_chemical_formula()))

    def __getattr__(self, attr):
        """ Forwards unknown attr to self._sites."""

        # Need to prevent recursion when deepcopying
        if attr == "__setstate__":
            raise AttributeError(attr)
        return self._sites.__getattribute__(attr)

    def __len__(self):
        """ Number of adsorption sites. """
        return len(self._original_indices)

    @cached_property
    def sites_in_cell(self) -> List[int]:
        """ Returns the indices of the sites that are in the unit cell. """
        # important to not make 1 inclusive. Else, equivalent points on lattice vectors would be duplicated
        # rounding needed for np arrays is to prevent numerical errors i.e  0.999999999 == 1
        frac_coord_rounded = np.round(self._original_frac_coords, 10)
        sites_in_cell = [i for i, v in enumerate(frac_coord_rounded) if np.all(np.logical_and(v >= 0, v < 1))]

        return sites_in_cell

    @cached_property
    def top_coords(self):
        return self._original_coordinates[self._original_connectivity == 1].copy()

    @property
    def slab(self):
        return self._sites.slab.copy()

    @property
    def cell(self):
        return self.slab.cell.copy()

    @cached_property
    def center_of_mass(self):
        return self.slab.get_center_of_mass()

    @cached_property
    def _original_connectivity(self) -> np.ndarray:
        return self._sites.connectivity

    @cached_property
    def _original_avg_coord_num(self) -> np.ndarray:
        """ For each site, gets the average coordination number over all surface atoms it is bonded to.
        Use repeated slab to get neighbours as initial slab may be too small such that its only neighbours
        are its periodic images (which is not found in get_neighbours() method)
        """
        repeated_slab = self.slab.repeat((3, 3, 1))
        repeated_slab = IAtomsWrapper.from_atoms(
            repeated_slab, precompute_distances=True)
        coord_nums = []

        for bonded_atoms in self._r1_topology_wrapped_slab():
            coords = [len(repeated_slab.get_neighbours(atom_idx=idx, cutoff_distance=3.2)) for idx in bonded_atoms]
            coord_nums.append(np.mean(coords))
        coord_nums = np.array(coord_nums)
        return coord_nums

    @cached_property
    def _original_coordinates(self) -> np.ndarray:
        return self._sites.coordinates

    @cached_property
    def _original_frac_coords(self) -> np.ndarray:
        return Coordinates(self._original_coordinates, cell=self.cell).frac_coordinates

    @cached_property
    def frac_coords(self):
        return self._original_frac_coords[self.selected_sites]

    @cached_property
    def connectivity(self):
        return self._original_connectivity[self.selected_sites]

    @cached_property
    def avg_coord_num(self):
        return self._original_avg_coord_num[self.selected_sites]

    @cached_property
    def coordinates(self):
        return self._original_coordinates[self.selected_sites]

    @cached_property
    def connectivity_in_cell(self):
        return self._original_connectivity[self.sites_in_cell]

    @cached_property
    def avg_coord_num_in_cell(self):
        return self._original_avg_coord_num[self.sites_in_cell]

    @cached_property
    def coordinates_in_cell(self):
        return self._original_coordinates[self.sites_in_cell]

    @cached_property
    def frac_coords_in_cell(self):
        return self._original_frac_coords[self.sites_in_cell]

    @property
    def sites_in_cell_atoms(self) -> AtomsWrapper:
        """AtomsWrapper object representing the lattice of sites in the unit cell."""
        atm = {1: 'X', 2: 'He', 3: 'F', 4: 'Ne'}
        sites_atoms = Atoms(cell=self.cell)
        for i, c in enumerate(self.coordinates_in_cell):
            typ = self.connectivity_in_cell[i]
            sites_atoms += Atom(atm[typ], c + [0, 0, 3])
        return AtomsWrapper.from_atoms(sites_atoms)



[docs]
    def adsorbate_decorated_slab(self) -> AtomsWrapper:
        """
        Returns:
            AtomsWrapper: AtomsWrapper object representing the selected sites. Atom indices matches the site indices.
        """
        decorated_slab = Atoms(cell=self.slab.cell)
        atm = {1: 'X', 2: 'He', 3: 'F', 4: 'Ne'}
        coordinates = [c + [0, 0, 3] for c in self.coordinates]

        for i, c in enumerate(coordinates):
            while len(decorated_slab) <= self.selected_sites[i]:
                decorated_slab += Atom()
            typ = self.connectivity[i]
            decorated_slab[self.selected_sites[i]].symbol = atm[typ]
            decorated_slab[self.selected_sites[i]].position = c
        decorated_slab += self.slab.copy()
        return AtomsWrapper.from_atoms(decorated_slab)



    @property
    def sites_lattice(self) -> Lattice:
        # TODO: repeat the lattice by 3x3 and match indices of catkit's sites to the newer and nicer lattice.
        # This is to allow us to use hash to determine unique structures, even for sites that are currently outside of the unit cell.
        """Lattice object representing the sites in cell."""
        return Lattice.from_atoms(self.sites_in_cell_atoms)

    @cached_property
    def sites_hash(self) -> list:
        """ Returns an integer hash for each site in cell. """
        if self.precomputed_hash is not None:
            return self.precomputed_hash

        def _get_hash(val):
            """Same hashed algo used in GraphHashingCalculator"""
            val = str(val)
            return np.mod(int(hashlib.md5(val.encode()).hexdigest(), 16), 65536) + 1

        def group_hash_values(val, groups):
            grouping = [val in group for group in groups]
            if any(grouping):
                return _get_hash(grouping.index(True))
            else:
                assert False, f'{val} not in {groups}'
        
        logger.debug(f'Hashing sites for {self}')
        # use symmetry filter to get the different groups
        group_indices = self._group_sites()
        sites_hash = [group_hash_values(i, group_indices)
                      for i, _ in enumerate(self.sites_in_cell)]
        return sites_hash

    def get_sites_info(self, sites=None) -> NamedTuple:
        """ Returns the properties of a list of sites/clusters.

        Single sites are treated as clusters of length 1:
            i.e., SitesInfo.coordinates[0] refers to each cluster, SitesInfo.coordinates[0][0] refers to the first site in the cluster.

        Args:
            sites (list): List of site indices. Defaults to self.selected_sites.
        Returns:
            SitesInfo (namedtuple): NamedTuple containing the coordinates, connectivity, avg_coord_num for the sites.
        """
        if sites is None:
            sites = self.selected_sites

        SitesInfo = namedtuple('SitesInfo', ['coordinates', 'connectivity', 'avg_coord_num', 'sites'])

        coordinates = self._original_coordinates[sites].tolist()
        connectivity = self._original_connectivity[sites].tolist()
        avg_coord_num = self._original_avg_coord_num[sites].tolist()

        return SitesInfo(coordinates, connectivity, avg_coord_num, sites)

    def filter_sites_in_cell(self):
        """ Filters self.selected_sites to sites that are in the unit cell.
        Returns:
            self (SitesLattice): Returns a new SitesLattice object with updated selected_sites.
        """
        selected_sites = [site for site in self.selected_sites if site in self.sites_in_cell]
        logger.info(f'{len(selected_sites)} sites after filter_sites_in_cell')
        return self.new(selected_sites=selected_sites)





[docs]
    def filter_distances(self, point, min_distance=0, max_distance=100, mic=False):
        """ Filters off sites that are too near or too far from point.
        Args:
            point (list): Coordinates of a point to filter sites from.
            min_distance (float): Sites < min_distance will be deselected
            max_distance (float): Sites > max_distance will be deselected
            mic (bool): Whether to use minimum image convention. Defaults to False.

        Returns:
            self (SitesLattice): Returns a new SitesLattice object with updated selected_sites.
        """
        c = Coordinates(coordinates=self.coordinates, cell=self.cell)
        distances = c.get_distances_from_point(point=point, mic=mic)
        mask = [i > min_distance and i < max_distance for i in distances]
        selected_sites = self.selected_sites[mask]

        return self.new(selected_sites)





[docs]
    def filter_direction(self, point, vec, dir_tol=0.5):
        """ Return sites that are in the same XY vector direction as the XY dissociation vector.
        Args:
            point (list): Coordinates of a point to filter sites from.
            vec (list): XY dissociation vector.
            dir_tol (float): value between -1 and 1. i.e., vec=(0,-1,0), tol: {-1:0°-360°, 0:90°-270°, 1:270°}. 

        Returns:
            self (SitesLattice): Returns a new SitesLattice object with updated selected_sites.    
        """
        # omit z direction
        point, vec = point[0:2], vec[0:2]
        xy_coords = [c[0:2] for c in self.coordinates]
        xy_site_vec = [point[0:2] - c for c in xy_coords]

        slab = AtomsWrapper.from_atoms(self.slab)
        directions = [slab.get_dot_product_direction_from_vectors(vec, v)[0] for v in xy_site_vec]

        mask = [d >= dir_tol for d in directions]
        selected_sites = self.selected_sites[mask]

        return self.new(selected_sites)

    def filter_index(self, index: List[int]):
        """ Filters sites from a list of site indices.
        Args:
            index (list): List of site indices to filter from.

        Returns:
            self (SitesLattice): Returns a new SitesLattice object with updated selected_sites.
        """
        site_criteria = [Sites.from_value(i) for i in index]
        mask = [any([s in site for site in site_criteria]) for s in self.selected_sites]

        selected_sites = self.selected_sites[mask]
        logger.info(f'{len(selected_sites)} sites after filter_index')
        return self.new(selected_sites)

    def sort_sites_by_distances(self, point=None):
        """ Sorts the site indices to the distance from point. Sorting allows for equivalent sites in the center to be selected.
        Args:
            point (list): Coordinates of a point to sort sites from. Defaults to slab's center of mass.
        Returns:
            self (SitesLattice): Returns a new SitesLattice object with updated selected_sites.
        """
        if point is None:
            point = self.center_of_mass

        distances = Coordinates(coordinates=self.coordinates,
                                cell=self.cell).get_distances_from_point(point=point, mic=True)

        indices = np.argsort(distances)
        selected_sites = self.selected_sites[indices]

        logger.info(f'Sites sorted according to distances to {point}')
        return self.new(selected_sites)



    def _group_sites(self) -> list:
        """ Uses StructuralSelfConsistentGrouper to determine the unique sites in cell. 

        Speed up -> Group sites according to unique connectivities and avg_coord_num first to reduce
        the group size of which StructuralSelfConsistentGrouper needs to compare. For example,
        [site1, site2, site3] -> [[site1], [site2, site3]] if site2 and 3 has the same C & ACN.

        Returns:
            group_indices (list): List of lists of site indices that are equivalent.
        """
        sites_avg_coord_num_rounded = [round(i, 2) for i in self.avg_coord_num_in_cell]
        site_information = list(zip(self.connectivity_in_cell, sites_avg_coord_num_rounded))
        unique_site_information = set(site_information)

        group_indices = []
        for s in unique_site_information:
            indices = [i for i, v in enumerate(site_information) if v == s]
            dummy_adsorbed_states = self.get_dummy_adsorbed_states(self.sites_in_cell)
            new_atoms = [dummy_adsorbed_states[i] for i in indices]

            from catplat.settings.constants import STRUCTURE_MATCHER_TOL_SITES, NUM_PROCS_SITES
            grouper = StructuralSelfConsistentGrouper.from_atoms(atoms=new_atoms,
                                                                 scale=False,
                                                                 num_procs=NUM_PROCS_SITES,
                                                                 stol=STRUCTURE_MATCHER_TOL_SITES)
            _, idx_grouped = grouper.group()
            for g in idx_grouped:
                group_indices += [[indices[i] for i in g]]

        return group_indices



[docs]
    def filter_unique_sites(self):
        """
        Filters sites that are not unique in the unit cell.

        Returns:
            self (SitesLattice): Returns a new SitesLattice object with updated selected_sites.

        Raises:
            IndexError: if self.selected_sites is not in self.sites_in_cell.
        """
        if not set(self.selected_sites).issubset(set(self.sites_in_cell)):
            raise IndexError(
                f'filter_unique_sites() only valid when selected_sites are in cell. Please run filter_sites_in_cell() first.')

        hashes_dict = dict(zip(self.sites_in_cell, self.sites_hash))
        selected_sites_hash = [hashes_dict[idx] for idx in self.selected_sites]
        mask = [selected_sites_hash.index(i) for i in set(selected_sites_hash)]

        selected_sites = self.selected_sites[mask]
        logger.info(f'{len(selected_sites)} sites after filter_unique_sites')

        return self.new(selected_sites, precomputed_hash=self.sites_hash)

    def get_edges_physical_distance(self, lower_tol: float, upper_tol: float) -> List[tuple[int, int]]:
        """ Get pairs of sites that fit the distance between vertices of the adsorbate.
        Args:
            lower_tol (float): Lower distance tolerance in Angstrom.
            upper_tol (float): Upper distance tolerance in Angstrom.

        Returns:
            edges (list): List of edges.
        """
        # get all sites within upper and lower distance tol
        all_distances = Coordinates(self._original_coordinates).get_all_distances()
        distances_from_selected_sites = all_distances[self.selected_sites]

        good_neighbours = [[idx for idx, dist in enumerate(
            d) if dist > lower_tol and dist < upper_tol] for d in distances_from_selected_sites]

        edges = [[(self.selected_sites[idx], neighbour) for neighbour in neighbours]
                 for idx, neighbours in enumerate(good_neighbours)]

        edges = list(chain.from_iterable(edges))

        # remove identical edges generated from different initial sites.
        edges = [tuple(sorted(e)) for e in edges]
        edges = list(set(edges))

        logger.info(f'{len(edges)} edges after get_edges_physical_distance')

        return edges

    def filter_equivalent_clusters(self, clusters: list, symmetrical: bool, num_procs=None) -> list:
        """" Filter off identical structures.
        Speedup -> Check equivalence using GraphHashingCalculator if possible. Else, use StructureMatcher.

        Args:
            clusters (list): List of clusters.
            symmetrical (bool): Whether to treat A-B == B-A.
            num_procs (int): Number of processors to filter clusters.

        Returns:
            clusters (list): List of unique clusters.
        """
        # quickly remove identical clusters
        clusters = list(set(clusters))

        if len(clusters) == 1:
            return clusters

        if symmetrical:
            clusters_w_hashes = [cluster for cluster in clusters if set(cluster).issubset(set(self.sites_in_cell))]
            clusters_wo_hashes = [cluster for cluster in clusters if not set(cluster).issubset(set(self.sites_in_cell))]
        else:
            clusters_w_hashes = []
            clusters_wo_hashes = clusters

        logger.info(f"{len(clusters)} clusters to be filtered by symmetry."
                    f"{len(clusters_w_hashes)} by hashes and {len(clusters_wo_hashes)} by StructureMatcher.")

        if len(clusters_w_hashes):
            calculator = GraphHashingCalculator.from_graph(self.sites_lattice.graph, adjustment_factors=self.sites_hash)

            hashes = [calculator.calc(*[self.sites_in_cell.index(site) for site in cluster])
                      for cluster in clusters_w_hashes]
            clusters = [clusters_w_hashes[hashes.index(i)] for i in set(hashes)]

        if len(clusters_wo_hashes):
            clusters = clusters + clusters_wo_hashes
            dummy_adsorbed_clusters = self.get_dummy_adsorbed_states(clusters, symmetrical=symmetrical)

            from catplat.settings.constants import STRUCTURE_MATCHER_TOL_SITES, NUM_PROCS_SITES
            if num_procs is None:
                num_procs = NUM_PROCS_SITES
            grouper = StructuralSelfConsistentGrouper.from_atoms(atoms=dummy_adsorbed_clusters,
                                                                 scale=False,
                                                                 num_procs=num_procs,
                                                                 stol=STRUCTURE_MATCHER_TOL_SITES)
            _, idx_grouped = grouper.group()
            clusters = [clusters[groups[0]] for groups in idx_grouped]

        logger.info(f'{len(clusters)} clusters after filter_equivalent_clusters')
        return clusters

    def filter_edges_connectivities(self, edges: list, connectivities: List[Union[int, Connectivity]],
                                    reverse: bool = False) -> list:
        """ Filter edges based on matching connectivities.
        Site(A-B) must match site A-B exactly or B-A if reverse is True.

        Args:
            edges (list): List of edge.
            connectivities (list): List of connectivities to match.
            reverse (bool): Whether to reverse the connectivity criteria. Defaults to False.

        Returns:
            edges (list): List of edges that matches the connectivity criteria.
        """

        connectivity_criteria = [Connectivity.from_value(i) for i in connectivities]

        if reverse:
            connectivity_criteria = [c.reverse() for c in connectivity_criteria]

        edges_connectivity = self.get_sites_info(edges).connectivity
        mask = [any([c.match(i) for c in connectivity_criteria]) for i in edges_connectivity]
        edges = [custer for custer, i in zip(edges, mask) if i]
        logger.info(f'{len(edges)} edges after filter_edges_connectivities')

        return edges

    def filter_edges_avg_coord_num(self, edges: list, avg_coord_num: list, reverse: bool = False) -> list:
        """ Filter a list of edges based on matching avg_coord_num.
        Site(A-B) must match site A-B exactly or B-A if reverse is True.

        Args:
            edges (list): List of edge.
            avg_coord_num (list): List of avg_coord_num to match.
            reverse (bool): Whether to reverse the avg_coord_num criteria. Defaults to False.

        Returns:
            edges (list): List of edges that matches the avg_coord_num criteria.
        """

        acn_criteria = [AverageCoordinationNumber.from_value(i) for i in avg_coord_num]

        if reverse:
            acn_criteria = [acn.reverse() for acn in acn_criteria]

        edges_avg_coord_num = self.get_sites_info(edges).avg_coord_num

        mask = [any([acn.match(i) for acn in acn_criteria]) for i in edges_avg_coord_num]
        edges = [edge for edge, i in zip(edges, mask) if i]

        logger.info(f'{len(edges)} edge after filter_edge_avg_coord_num')
        return edges

    def filter_edges_index(self, edges: list, index: list, reverse: bool = False):
        """ Filters an edge based on matching indices.
        Site(A-B) must match site A-B exactly or B-A if reverse is True.

        Args:
            edges (list): List of edge.
            index (list): List of indices to match.
            reverse (bool): Whether to reverse the index criteria. Defaults to False.

        Returns:
            edges (list): List of edge that matches the index criteria.
        """

        site_criteria = [Sites.from_value(i) for i in index]

        if reverse:
            site_criteria = [s.reverse() for s in site_criteria]

        mask = [any([s.match(edge) for s in site_criteria]) for edge in edges]
        edges = [edge for edge, i in zip(edges, mask) if i]

        logger.info(f'{len(edges)} edges after filter_edges_index.')
        return edges

    def filter_clusters_distance(self, clusters: list, distance_cutoff: float) -> list:
        """ Filter clusters that are too close to each other.
        Args:
            clusters (list): List of clusters.
            distance_tol (float): Distance cutoff in Angstrom.

        Returns:
            clusters_new (list): List of clusters that are not too close to each other.    
        """

        clusters_coords = self.get_sites_info(clusters).coordinates

        clusters_new = []
        for cluster_coords, cluster in zip(clusters_coords, clusters):
            all_distances = Coordinates(cluster_coords, cell=self.slab.cell).get_all_distances(mic=True)
            # fill diagonal with arbituary value as diagonal == distance from itself == 0
            np.fill_diagonal(all_distances, 100)

            if np.all(all_distances > distance_cutoff):
                clusters_new.append(cluster)

        return clusters_new

    def sites_in_clusters(self, clusters: list, sites: list) -> list:
        """ Checks a list of cluster and returns cluster if all the site in sites are in cluster. """
        site_criteria = [Sites.from_value(i) for i in sites]

        mask = [all([s.match_any(cluster) for s in site_criteria]) for cluster in clusters]
        clusters = [cluster for cluster, i in zip(clusters, mask) if i]

        logger.info(f'{len(clusters)} clusters after sites_in_clusters.')
        return clusters

    def new(self, selected_sites: np.ndarray, precomputed_hash=None):
        """ Returns a new instance of SitesLattice with updated selected_sites.

        Use caching as new is called many times in filter functions, creating new instances of SitesLattice,
        and each new instance has to recompute the unique sites in cell, which is slow. Caching allows us to
        reuse the same instance of SitesLattice whenever we filter, which is much faster.

        Args:
            selected_sites (list): List of site indices.
            precomputed_hash (list): List of precomputed hashes for each site. Defaults to None.
        """

        if precomputed_hash is None:
            precomputed_hash = self.precomputed_hash

        if precomputed_hash is not None:
            precomputed_hash = tuple(precomputed_hash)

        selected_sites = tuple(selected_sites)

        return self._new_cached(selected_sites, precomputed_hash)


    @lru_cache(maxsize=64)
    def _new_cached(self, selected_sites, precomputed_hash):
        return type(self)(sites=self._sites,
                          selected_sites=selected_sites,
                          precomputed_hash=precomputed_hash)

    def get_dummy_adsorbed_states(self, sites: list, symmetrical: bool = False) -> List[AtomsWrapper]:
        """ Returns images of len(sites), with each image corresponding to each site in sites.
        Args:
            sites (list): List of site indices or list of clusters.
            symmetrical (bool): Whether to treat A1-A2 == A2-A1.
        Returns:
            images (list): List of AtomsWrapper objects."""

        if len(sites) == 0:
            return []

        def _create_dummy_image(coordinates, symmetrical) -> AtomsWrapper:
            """ Creates a dummy image based on a list of coordinates."""
            image = self.slab.copy()
            if symmetrical:
                dummy_adsorbates = [Atoms(symbols='X', positions=[np.array(c) + [0, 0, 3]])
                                    for c in coordinates]
            else:
                dummy_adsorbates = [Atoms(symbols=f'X{str(i + 1)}', positions=[np.array(c) + [0, 0, 3]] * (i + 1))
                                    for i, c in enumerate(coordinates)]

            for dummy_adsorbate in dummy_adsorbates:
                image += dummy_adsorbate

            return image.to_atomswrapper()

        # Treating each element in sites as a cluster of sites (regardless of whether i is int/List[int])
        # helps to generalize the function to work for sites/edges/clusters.
        clusters = [Sites.from_value(i) for i in sites]
        clusters_info = self.get_sites_info(clusters)
        images = [_create_dummy_image(coordinates=c, symmetrical=symmetrical) for c in clusters_info.coordinates]
        return images

    def get_clusters(self, quantity: int) -> List[tuple[int, ...]]:
        """ Return a list of clusters with each cluster having {quantity} number of sites.
        Args:
            quantity (int): Number of sites in each cluster.

        Returns:
            clusters (list): List of clusters.
        """

        if len(self.selected_sites) < quantity:
            raise ValueError(f"Number of selected sites ({len(self.selected_sites)}) < quantity ({quantity}).")

        clusters = list(combinations(self.selected_sites, quantity))
        clusters = [tuple(i) for i in clusters]
        logger.info(f"{len(clusters)} clusters after get_clusters")
        return clusters



    def _r1_topology_wrapped_slab(self):
        """
        Generates r1_topology with indices corresponding to the atoms of the wrapped instead of extended slab.
        Reverse engineers the code in catkit.gen.adsorption.AdsorptionSites that generates the adsorption sites.
        """

        # Create mapping of atom in extended slab to the atoms in wrapped slab
        extended_slab_atoms, _, _ = utils.expand_cell(self.slab, cutoff=5.0)

        # Indices of surface atoms in the wrapped slab
        surface_atoms = self.slab.get_surface_atoms()

        # Indices of surface atoms in the extended slab
        extended_surface_atoms = np.where(np.in1d(extended_slab_atoms, surface_atoms))[0]

        # Indices in r1 topology are based upon the extended_surface_atoms, as opposed to the extended_slab_atoms
        r1_topology_wrapped_slab = []
        for top_indices in self.r1_topology:
            # Get the atom indices of extended slab
            new_indices = extended_surface_atoms[top_indices]

            # Mapping back from the extended slab to the wrapped slab
            new_indices = extended_slab_atoms[new_indices]

            r1_topology_wrapped_slab += [list(new_indices)]
        return r1_topology_wrapped_slab

    def distances_to(self, point: list, mic=True):
        """ Get distances of all selected sites to a specified point.
        Args:
            point (list): Coordinates of the point
            mic (bool): To use minimum image convention or not. Defaults to True.
        """

        coordinates = Coordinates(self.coordinates, self.cell) + Coordinates(point)
        return coordinates.get_distances(indices1=-1, indices2=range(len(self)), mic=mic)

    @classmethod
    def from_slab(cls, slab, tol=1E-5, angle_tol=0.01):
        """ Create adsorption sites from slab.
        Args:
            slab (Gratoms): Gratoms object that represents the slab.
            tol (float): Tolerance that goes into AdsorptionSites. Defaults to 1E-5.
            angle_tol (float): Tolerance for right angle detection via testing of the inner product,
                which ranges from 0 - 1). Defaults to 0.05.
        Raises:
            ValueError: If slab does not have surface atoms.
        """

        # If pbc is not [True, True, False], adsorption sites will be very wrong
        slab = slab.copy()
        slab.pbc = [True, True, False]

        try:
            surface_atoms = slab.get_surface_atoms()
        except (AttributeError, KeyError):
            from catplat.structure.surface import Surface
            surface = Surface.from_atoms(slab)
            slab = surface.gratoms()
            surface_atoms = slab.get_surface_atoms()

        if surface_atoms is None or len(surface_atoms) == 0:
            raise ValueError('Slab does not have surface atoms')

        slab = IGratomsWrapper.from_atoms(slab)
        return cls._from_slab_cached(slab=slab, tol=tol, angle_tol=angle_tol)



    @classmethod
    @lru_cache(maxsize=64)
    def _from_slab_cached(cls, slab, tol, angle_tol):
        # Monkeypatch AdsorptionSites to help identify 4-fold hollow sites more easily
        # Instead of partial use partialmethod -> partial for instance methods,
        # supplies `self` argument as first positional argument
        func = partialmethod(_get_higher_coordination_sites, allow_obtuse=True, angle_tol=angle_tol)
        AdsorptionSites._get_higher_coordination_sites = func

        sites = AdsorptionSites(slab=slab, tol=tol)
        logger.info(f'Created new adsorption sites for slab {slab}')
        return cls(sites=sites)




def _get_higher_coordination_sites(self, top_coordinates, allow_obtuse=True, angle_tol=0.05):
    """
    Monkey patched function for AdsorptionSites()._get_higher_coordination_sites() to fix bug where
    connectivity 4 sites were not correctly identified.
    """
    sites = {
        'top': [top_coordinates, [], [[] for _ in top_coordinates]],
        'bridge': [[], [], []],
        'hollow': [[], [], []],
        '4fold': [[], [], []]}

    dt = scipy.spatial.Delaunay(sites['top'][0][:, :2])
    neighbors = dt.neighbors
    simplices = dt.simplices

    from pyatoms.utils.coordinates import Coordinates
    from pyatoms.utils.geometry import Plane
    coordinates = Coordinates(sites['top'][0])

    for i, corners in enumerate(simplices):
        cir = scipy.linalg.circulant(corners)
        edges = cir[:, 1:]

        # Inner angle of each triangle corner
        vec = sites['top'][0][edges.T] - sites['top'][0][corners]
        uvec = vec.T / np.linalg.norm(vec, axis=2).T
        angles = np.sum(uvec.T[0] * uvec.T[1], axis=1)

        # Angle types
        right = np.isclose(angles, 0, atol=angle_tol)
        obtuse = (angles < -angle_tol)

        rh_corner = corners[right]
        edge_neighbors = neighbors[i]

        if obtuse.any() and not allow_obtuse:
            # Assumption: All simplices with obtuse angles
            # are irrelevant boundaries.
            continue

        bridge = np.sum(sites['top'][0][edges], axis=1) / 2.0

        # Looping through corners allows for elimination of
        # redundant points, identification of 4-fold hollows,
        # and collection of bridge neighbors.
        for j, c in enumerate(corners):
            edge = sorted(edges[j])

            if edge in sites['bridge'][1]:
                continue

            # Get the bridge neighbors (for adsorption vector)
            neighbor_simplex = simplices[edge_neighbors[j]]
            oc = list(set(neighbor_simplex) - set(edge))[0]

            # Right angles potentially indicate 4-fold hollow
            potential_hollow = edge + sorted([c, oc])
            if c in rh_corner:

                if potential_hollow in sites['4fold'][1]:
                    continue

                # ===================================================================
                # catplat: Check that all angles are not obtuse angles
                # Important to prevent spurious detection of 4 fold hollow sites at boundaries.
                # Overwrites the value of "oright" calculated above.
                # ===================================================================
                from itertools import permutations as perms
                all_angles = np.array([coordinates.get_angle(
                    *c, degrees=False) for c in perms(potential_hollow, 3)])
                oright = not np.any(all_angles < -angle_tol)
                # ===================================================================

                if oright:
                    # ================================================================
                    # catplat: Only if all 4 points are coplanar, then it is a valid 4 fold hollow site.
                    # e.g. If the 4 points represent the corners of a tetrahedron,
                    #      then even though all angles are not obtuse angles,
                    #      it is not a valid 4 fold hollow site.
                    # ================================================================
                    hollow_coords = sites['top'][0][potential_hollow]
                    plane = Plane.from_points(hollow_coords[:3])
                    is_coplanar = plane.distance(hollow_coords[-1]) < 1E-1

                    if is_coplanar:
                        sites['4fold'][0] += [bridge[j]]
                        sites['4fold'][1] += [potential_hollow]
                        sites['top'][2][c] += [oc]
            else:
                sites['bridge'][0] += [bridge[j]]
                sites['bridge'][1] += [edge]
                sites['bridge'][2] += [[c, oc]]

            sites['top'][2][edge[0]] += [edge[1]]
            sites['top'][2][edge[1]] += [edge[0]]

        if not right.any() and not obtuse.any():
            hollow = np.average(sites['top'][0][corners], axis=0)
            sites['hollow'][0] += [hollow]
            sites['hollow'][1] += [corners.tolist()]

    # For collecting missed bridge neighbors
    for s in sites['4fold'][1]:

        edges = itertools.product(s[:2], s[2:])
        for edge in edges:
            edge = sorted(edge)
            i = sites['bridge'][1].index(edge)
            n, m = sites['bridge'][1][i], sites['bridge'][2][i]
            nn = list(set(s) - set(n + m))

            if len(nn) == 0:
                continue
            sites['bridge'][2][i] += [nn[0]]

    return sites
